element.name: Jack the Bachelor by Windsockers, Multi-cache (5/5)

long-description.p: Jack the Bachelor and Jack Field are names for a smuggler called Jack Connor, who lived in Rush. Connor was a native of Wexford. who practiced his trade from the Smugglers Cave between Loughshinney and Skerries, Connor was a romantic and swashbuckling character, and was very popular in high society circles. One 18th. Century ballad mentions him in a particularly rich-worded verse:
all these joys are but vain they are blended with pain
I'll stand behind Field and my glass"

A number of stories circulate about Jack's cave, most claiming it holds treasure. One rather far-fetched version has a huge green serpent guarding the treasure. Another has two men going in search of the riches, never to be seen again. Presumably the serpent got them. Others say that the cave extends as far as Baldongan Castle. "Jack the Bachelor" is buried in Kenure graveyard.

The Cliff path to the smugglers cave (a mine outlet) which is reputed to have been used by smugglers to store their goods during the late 18th century, has all but disappeared due to coastal erosion but it is still possible to go by the seashore at low tide with a local guide.

The smuggling trade became very lucrative in the Rush/Loughshinny area after the British Government imposed excise duties on a large number of goods. In 1765 the use of the Isle of Man as a centre for warehousing ceased as the British took possession of the island and so about fifty large vessels in the area of Rush became involved in the smuggling trade.

p.b: Before you can start this cache you will need to complete "Woar War" for some relevant information.

long-description.p: You need to check local tide times for parts of this cache. Access to the coast is only available at Loughshinny or Skerries. Please do not attempt to access the coast from the road between these two places as you would have to cross private land and there would also be some dangerous scrambling involved.
I STRONGLY advise that you commence this cache at part one at least two hours before low tide and this assumes that you have the necessary codes from "WOAR WAR" already.
You can check local tide times Here
Walking boots are a must and you may need wellies as well.
This is not a cache for children as coastal errosion has created some areas of difficulty and danger. Please be extremely careful while scrambling on any seaweed covered rocks.
At the above coordinates you will find the grave of Jack“The Bachelor”Connor. Nearby you will find some coordinates for part two of this cache.
You will find more coordinates here after which you will need to go to Jacks hiding place listed on a stone slab nearby.
Here you will find a number of letters etched by Jack abbreviating his favorite cat. The coordinates for the final cache will be made up as follows:

Take the number of letters first and place it at “A” below. Convert the first letter to a number as per ABC=123 and place it at B below. Using the same system add the first and second letters together and place the answer at C below.

p.b: The final coordinates for the cache are N53 A2.96C W006 04.BBC

element.additional-waypoints:

element.encoded-hints: Part 1. 9 paces South.Part 2 Part 3. Add one of his "aliases" to confirm Part 4. Concrete Stone.

ul.li:
2008-10-25T19:00:00Z : Didn't find it by daraconn
Went back to the first stage of Jack the Bachelor this morning, and found the new "better" co-ordinates. We set out with hope to find the second stage, but sadly the new co-ordinates put us in inaccessible territory in a private field. Much aimless and repetitive searching ensued, prompting curiosity and questions from the neighbours (who are becoming used to seeing me poking around in their flowerbeds). No result. Where to go from here?

2008-08-01T19:00:00Z : Found it by snoopyandmickey
After doing woar wars years ago I can honestly say this is the hardest, longest cache I have ever done. The other half of the team gave up on the first visit, I wrecked a pair of craghopper trousers on this visit, burned out a set of batteries on my torch in one go, The rain nearly drowned me and I may give up caching! Kidding. Seriously tho a great cache on reflection. Got stuck at stage 2 so went back to the start and systematically went though it again. 5 star terrain was very appropriate in this weather. Not saying any more cos it took me a year and a half. Beat that! Left a very worthy yellow stretchy man.

2008-07-27T19:00:00Z : Write note by Fjon
Stage one is definitely still there, and legible. I found it today. Will have to come back to do stage two though - not as easy!

2008-07-11T19:00:00Z : Write note by snoopyandmickey
Having found Woar wars ages ago I had started this cache last year and got some info. However after moving house last September and getting a new pc I lost the info. I returned yesterday (as I am working in the area every Thursday) but couldnt read the info at stage one.... I thought this was going to be easy... [:I]

2008-07-11T12:27:19Z : Temporarily Disable Listing by Windsockers
As its a 5*5* it not meant to be easy [:O][:O][:O]
I'll take a look at the start asap I'm sure the cache is still in place as the previous dnf's indicate that not all the stages were completed [8)][8)]

wpt.name: GCWBCT
wpt.desc: Jack the Bachelor by Windsockers, Multi-cache (5/5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Jack the Bachelor
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Jack the Bachelor

Jack the Bachelor and Jack Field are names for a smuggler called Jack Connor, who lived in Rush. Connor was a native of Wexford. who practiced his trade from the Smugglers Cave between Loughshinney and Skerries, Connor was a romantic and swashbuckling character, and was very popular in high society circles. One 18th. Century ballad mentions him in a particularly rich-worded verse:

"The lover may sigh

the courtier may lie

And Croesus his treasure amass,

all these joys are but vain they are blended with pain

I'll stand behind Field and my glass"

A number of stories circulate about Jack's cave, most claiming it holds treasure. One rather far-fetched version has a huge green serpent guarding the treasure. Another has two men going in search of the riches, never to be seen again. Presumably the serpent got them. Others say that the cave extends as far as Baldongan Castle. "Jack the Bachelor" is buried in Kenure graveyard.

The Smugglers Cave

The Cliff path to the smugglers cave (a mine outlet) which is reputed to have been used by smugglers to store their goods during the late 18th century, has all but disappeared due to coastal erosion but it is still possible to go by the seashore at low tide with a local guide.

The smuggling trade became very lucrative in the Rush/Loughshinny area after the British Government imposed excise duties on a large number of goods. In 1765 the use of the Isle of Man as a centre for warehousing ceased as the British took possession of the island and so about fifty large vessels in the area of Rush became involved in the smuggling trade.


The Cache

Before you can start this cache you will need to complete "Woar War" for some relevant information.


WARNING!

You need to check local tide times for parts of this cache. Access to the coast is only available at Loughshinny or Skerries. Please do not attempt to access the coast from the road between these two places as you would have to cross private land and there would also be some dangerous scrambling involved.

I STRONGLY advise that you commence this cache at part one at least two hours before low tide and this assumes that you have the necessary codes from "WOAR WAR" already.

You can check local tide times Here

Walking boots are a must and you may need wellies as well.

This is not a cache for children as coastal errosion has created some areas of difficulty and danger. Please be extremely careful while scrambling on any seaweed covered rocks.


Part one

At the above coordinates you will find the grave of Jack“The Bachelor”Connor. Nearby you will find some coordinates for part two of this cache.

Part Two

You will find more coordinates here after which you will need to go to Jacks hiding place listed on a stone slab nearby.

Part Three

Here you will find a number of letters etched by Jack abbreviating his favorite cat. The coordinates for the final cache will be made up as follows:

Take the number of letters first and place it at “A” below. Convert the first letter to a number as per ABC=123 and place it at B below. Using the same system add the first and second letters together and place the answer at C below.

Part four

The final coordinates for the cache are N53 A2.96C W006 04.BBC



The Windsockers

Additional Waypoints

FLWBCT - Final Location
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___

S2WBCT - Stage 2
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___

S3WBCT - Stage 3
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___

S4WBCT - Stage 4
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:encoded_hints: Part 1. 9 paces South.Part 2 Part 3. Add one of his "aliases" to confirm Part 4. Concrete Stone.

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Went back to the first stage of Jack the Bachelor this morning, and found the new "better" co-ordinates. We set out with hope to find the second stage, but sadly the new co-ordinates put us in inaccessible territory in a private field. Much aimless and repetitive searching ensued, prompting curiosity and questions from the neighbours (who are becoming used to seeing me poking around in their flowerbeds). No result. Where to go from here?

After doing woar wars years ago I can honestly say this is the hardest, longest cache I have ever done. The other half of the team gave up on the first visit, I wrecked a pair of craghopper trousers on this visit, burned out a set of batteries on my torch in one go, The rain nearly drowned me and I may give up caching! Kidding. Seriously tho a great cache on reflection. Got stuck at stage 2 so went back to the start and systematically went though it again. 5 star terrain was very appropriate in this weather. Not saying any more cos it took me a year and a half. Beat that! Left a very worthy yellow stretchy man.
Stage one is definitely still there, and legible. I found it today. Will have to come back to do stage two though - not as easy!

Having found Woar wars ages ago I had started this cache last year and got some info. However after moving house last September and getting a new pc I lost the info. I returned yesterday (as I am working in the area every Thursday) but couldnt read the info at stage one.... I thought this was going to be easy... [:I]

As its a 5*5* it not meant to be easy [:O][:O][:O]
I'll take a look at the start asap I'm sure the cache is still in place as the previous dnf's indicate that not all the stages were completed [8)][8)]
